thread.title: Local pediatric heart disease foundation continues to grow
thread.title_full: Local pediatric heart disease foundation continues to grow - Orlando Sentinel

author: orlandosentinel.com
title: Local pediatric heart disease foundation continues to grow
text:
It’s Congenital Heart Disease Awareness Week, and the local foundation Yellow Brick Road wants you to support the cause by using #CHDAware.
The Flynn family started the Yellow Brick Road Foundation in memory of their son Holden who died in January 2014 while waiting for a heart transplant.
“CHD holds families hostage,” said Trey Flynn, Holden’s father and Yellow Brick Road’s founder, in a news release. “Any disease that affects 1 in 100 children deserves more public awareness.”
Congenital Heart Disease is the most common pediatric heart defect in the United States, affecting about 40,000 babies each year. Nearly a quarter of those babies need surgery, some of which are complex or can’t be repaired and require a heart transplant.
Starting local and small, Yellow Brick Road is on its way to become nationally-known, because of the Flynns’ dedication to their cause.
Yellow Brick Road Foundation donates wagons to Pediatric Cardiovascular ICU Trey & Nicole Flynn founded Yellow Brick Road after their son Holden passed from congenital heart disease. Their goals include donating wagons to pediatric hospitals. The wagon was a favorite for Holden, since with it he could leave his hospital bed. Trey & Nicole Flynn founded Yellow Brick Road after their son Holden passed from congenital heart disease. Their goals include donating wagons to pediatric hospitals. The wagon was a favorite for Holden, since with it he could leave his hospital bed. See more videos A Yellow Brick Road for little ailing hearts »
The husband and wife have become strong advocates of transparency, wanting pediatric heart surgery programs to publicly share their numbers and outcomes.
The Flynns are working with Pediatric Congenital Heart Association to create a consumer-friendly database of heart surgery programs and variety of resources of parents.
“As a parent, what’s important for me is that information is out there so parents can make decisions about which hospital they should go to,” said Flynn, an attorney with NeJame Law.
The foundation also provides different types of assistance for families who have a hospitalized child due to Congenital Heart Disease.
One of Yellow Brick Road’s trademarks is a customized wagon that allows small patients recovering from surgery take a trip around the hospital floor along with their IV bags. The foundation has donated several wagons to Orlando’s three children’s hospitals and is working on raising funds to donate more to other hospitals.
“We’re excited about what we’ve done so far,” said Flynn in an interview.
For more information, visit ybrf.org .
